subject: Resource Approval: Cursor Ultra & Efficiency Goals
preview:
Hi Evan!

We are happy to approve one month of Cursor Ultra for your course planning tool. We’ve been really impressed by your enthusiasm and commitment since you started in the spring.

Here's the login credentials (we are the only people it is share
body_html:
Hi Evan!

We are happy to approve one month of Cursor Ultra for your course planning tool. We’ve been really impressed by your enthusiasm and commitment since you started in the spring.

Here's the login credentials (we are the only people it is shared with, bu you can share it with your team members that need it too):

User Name: techlab-students_wsb@wisc.edu
Password : Sadly&Carrousel2&Human
We're really looking forward to seeing what you can do with the new tools. However, your current resource usage isn't sustainable for the Lab long-term. While you have the green light to finalize features for the Tech Exploration Lab Demo Night, we need you to focus part of your subscription capacity on internal efficiency rather than just expansion.
Here are a few areas where we suggest you look to improve resource usage:
  • Framework: Svelte 5 often requires cutting-edge, high-context models to write basic UI. The advantages of Svelte 5 are minor in comparison to the complexity it adds to AI tool workflos. Switching to a more established ecosystem could significantly reduce your "token tax."
  • Architecture: Moving toward a unified backend rather than separate pages for every major would be much more efficient.
  • Codebase: Structuring the code to avoid resubmitting the entire codebase for every request would help avoid "locking in" to expensive tiers. Looking at ways to build a seprataion of concerns between your codebase components will allow you to only have to use the context of those modules instead of all the code as a whole.
  • This is not an exhaustive list and you understand best where the complexies of your codebase stands, but these were the ones that came up based on what you've communicated about your work.
You don't need to fix everything at once, but showing measurable progress toward better resource efficiency is critical for our continued support.
Note: This month has a hard cap. If you burn through the subscription early, we cannot offer top-ups. Using a full Ultra subscription in under a month signals a need for better efficiency, not more compute.
Good luck with Demo Night!
Best,
UW Tech Exploration Lab

todos.content: Finalize features for the Tech Exploration Lab Demo Night
Switch to a more established ecosystem (instead of Svelte 5) to significantly reduce 'token tax'
Move toward a unified backend rather than separate pages for every major feature
Structure the code to avoid resubmitting the entire codebase for every request
Build a separation of concerns between codebase components

There is a minimum points purchase threshold on a per transaction basis to be eligible for a bonus. The percentage bonus amount will show for eligible members when they log into their IHG One Rewards account. (Please click through to access the landing page for the Offer.)

The number of points a member may purchase, gift, or receive as a gift during the Offer Period is subject to annual limits under the IHG One Rewards Membership Terms and Conditions, which are available on www.ihg.com. Members may only purchase a maximum of up to 200,000 points during a calendar year, so the number of points a member can purchase will depend on how many points the member had already purchased during the same calendar year. However, during the Offer Period, members may purchase a maximum of up to 300,000 points. For example, if a member had previously purchased 50,000 points in 2025, then the member could only purchase up to a maximum of 250,000 points during the Offer Period and would be eligible to receive the applicable percentage of additional bonus points under this Offer based only on the amount of points purchased during the Offer Period.

Similar limits apply to gifting points and receiving points as a gift: Members may purchase a maximum of 300,000 points during the Offer Period only. Members may gift a maximum of 300,000 points or receive as a gift from another member a combined maximum of 300,000 points during the Offer Period only. Points that have been already purchased, gifted or received as a gift in 2025 are included in the 300,000 points limit. Outside of the Offer Period, if a member purchases points that exceed the 200,000 points threshold for 2025 then they cannot purchase points for the remainder of the calendar year.

Purchased points, as well as any bonus points awarded under this Offer, do not count towards IHG One Rewards Elite status. subject: Join the FIRST EVER Humanoid Robotics Club in UW-Madison!!!
preview:
Join the FIRST EVER Humanoid Robotics club in UW-Madison!

In this club, we will be building a full humanoid robot with dexterous hands, custom actuators, and general-purpose intelligence through VLA (Vision Language Action) models. Our first interest m
body_html:
Join the FIRST EVER Humanoid Robotics club in UW-Madison!

In this club, we will be building a full humanoid robot with dexterous hands, custom actuators, and general-purpose intelligence through VLA (Vision Language Action) models. Our first interest meeting will be on December 2, 6:00-7:00 PM, Room 1610 Engineering Hall, and soon after that we’ll start to design our first prototype.

This is the team people will wish they joined a year from now, and we’re just starting, so you get to participate from the start: in this grand undertaking of building a Humanoid Robot from scratch! Do not miss out this opportunity. Tell your friends and everyone you know!


For more information:

Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/u6P5wu8ywc 
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/wiscohumanoids
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/wiscohumanoids/

Watch Teaser: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aw7vV4zyR4M 
Check Out Our Website: https://www.wiscohumanoids.com/

--

If you prefer to no longer receive information on campus events from your fellow classmates, you can unsubscribe by emailing all-student-bulletin-board+unsubscribe@g-groups.wisc.edu.

subject: Bench Exam Signup
preview: Everyone, There will be a bench exam during the days of 1 Dec to 4 Dec in 3654 (Plexus Lab). The exam is a 1h15mins long. It will happen during the normal lab time slot. So around 215PM to 345PM. In the near future, I will send everyone the web address of
body_html:
Everyone, There will be a bench exam during the days of 1 Dec to 4 Dec in 3654 (Plexus Lab). The exam is a 1h15mins long. It will happen during the normal lab time slot. So around 215PM to 345PM. In the near future, I will send everyone the web address of a Doodle pole that you will have to sign up on. You will select one, and only one, of the four days to take the exam on. Sign up early if you need a certain date. You will take the exam by yourself. You need to bring your breadboard and scope probes. The rest will be supplied to you in the lab.

 

The test is open book, open internet and you can use LTSpice as well as your own computer if you want to. You cannot use your cell phone.

 

Mark Allie

todos.content: Sign up for the bench exam using the Doodle poll once it's distributed.
Bring your breadboard and scope probes to the bench exam.

events.title: Bench Exam Period
events.content: The bench exam is 1 hour 15 minutes long and will take place during the normal lab time slot (approximately 2:15 PM to 3:45 PM) on one day chosen by the participant between December 1st and December 4th. The exam is open book, open internet, and allows LTSpice as well as personal computers. Cell phones are not permitted.

subject: Course Drop Deadline and Update on grading ECE 230: ECE230: Circuit Analysis (001) FA25
preview:
Hello ECE 230 Students,

I would like to kindly remind you that the course-drop deadline is Monday, November 24.

Additionally, I have decided not to enforce the syllabus requirement that “a score of 60% on the exams is necessary to pass the course.”
body_html:
Hello ECE 230 Students,

I would like to kindly remind you that the course-drop deadline is Monday, November 24.

Additionally, I have decided not to enforce the syllabus requirement that “a score of 60% on the exams is necessary to pass the course.” As long as your overall course score is 60 or higher, you will receive a grade of D or above, per the syllabus guideline, which is provided below for your convenience. 

If you would like to discuss your grade or your decision to drop the course on Monday, I am available during class and office hours. Please review the MATLAB script sent earlier to perform your grade analysis.

From the syllabus (which will be applied) 

The minimum overall class average required to achieve each grade category is listed below
(assuming satisfactory class attendance, successful video quiz results, and higher than 60% of
exam score). Scores are not rounded before applying these thresholds. The actual cut-off
scores used may be lower, but they will not be higher.

93 – A 

88 – AB   

83 – B   

78 – BC 

 70 – C 

60 – D

Have a nice weekend, 

Bulent Sarlioglu, Ph.D.

Professor

subject: Spring Co-Op Orientation- TODAY (11/21)-- 3-4 pm, EH 1610
preview:
Good afternoon COE Undergrads,

If you have accepted a co-op offer for the Spring semester, please see important details regarding the upcoming Engineering Career Services Spring Co-op Orientation happening TODAY--

  *
Friday, November 21st from 3:0
body_html:
Good afternoon COE Undergrads,

If you have accepted a co-op offer for the Spring semester, please see important details regarding the upcoming Engineering Career Services Spring Co-op Orientation happening TODAY--
  • Friday, November 21st from 3:00-4:00 pm in Engineering Hall #1610

Attending an orientation is the first step in getting authorized for the required co-op course.  Attendance is welcomed regardless of whether you have reported your Spring co-op on Handshake or not.  During the orientation session, ECS will cover all aspects of the co-op process from reporting & authorization to course expectations.  Please make sure you attend!  You do not need to register for the session.  The orientation is scheduled as a 60 minute period.


You can find more Co-Op information by utilizing the link to the ECS webpage below:

https://ecs.wisc.edu/students/co-op-and-internship/academic-credit/



Drew Graf

Career Services Advisor

Engineering Career Services

University of Wisconsin-Madison

aagraf@wisc.edu

ecs.wisc.edu

608-262-3356

Schedule an Appointment: https://go.wisc.edu/ecs.appt.graf

subject: The UWPD Post – November 2025
preview:
WAIT! Don't Send the Pic.


It can start with a friendly message and end with threats or demands for money. Intimacy-based extortion is becoming more common, especially among college students. A few simple precautions can keep you safe when connecting
body_html:
WAIT! Don't Send the Pic.


It can start with a friendly message and end with threats or demands for money. Intimacy-based extortion is becoming more common, especially among college students. A few simple precautions can keep you safe when connecting online.


Read more »

Protecting Your Property During Breaks


Heading out of town for break? Before you lock the door and hit the road, it’s worth taking a moment to make sure your space and belongings are set up to stay secure while you’re away. A few quick preventive steps now can help you return to campus with peace of mind and no surprises.


Read more »

Horse Power


The UWPD Mounted Unit recently caught the attention of On Wisconsin Magazine, and for good reason. Their story highlights how our horses and riders bring approachability, visibility, and a unique sense of community to campus — whether they’re navigating game-day crowds, supporting major events, or simply creating moments of connection with students and visitors. It’s a behind-the-scenes look at the training, teamwork, and trust that make this unit so special.


Read more »

Survey Says.....


Your voice helps shape how we show up for our campus community. That’s why, every so often, we check in to hear how we’re doing and where we can do better.


Early next month, you’ll receive a short survey from UWPD. It takes just a few minutes and gives you the chance to share your experiences and feedback directly with us.


Look for it the week after Thanksgiving in your WiscMail inbox -- and thanks in advance for taking a moment to share your thoughts and suggestions!

That's a Wrap!


As temperatures drop, our Lake Rescue & Safety team has officially wrapped up another busy season on Lake Mendota.


From supporting hundreds of lake users to preparing for new upgrades next spring, plenty is happening behind the scenes. Catch up on what’s new—and what to keep in mind if you’re heading out on the water this winter.


Read more »

It's our monthly Spotlight on Your UWPD Squad! Each month, we'll put a UWPD employee in the spotlight. Learn why they are proud to serve you and your community, the reason they chose their profession, their favorite things about UW-Madison, and much more!

Cody Pharo

Police Officer


» Started at UWPD: February 2025

» Hometown: Mount Horeb, WI

» College: Madison College, Criminal Justice

» Shift: 1st Shift


What brought you to UWPD?

There are so many various opportunities offered at UWPD -- that's what drew me here.


What do you like most about working at UWPD and on the UW-Madison campus?

I really enjoy working with the people at the department -- and across campus.

What's something most people don't know about you?

I used to coach high school track and field -- shot put and discus.


What's your favorite Babcock Ice Cream flavor?

Caramel Creek


What's your favorite spot on campus?

Observatory Hill Overlook


Anything else you’d like to share?

I have two dogs. I also like to build things, and I'm constantly working on projects!

UWPD Daily Blotter


Did you know you can view our significant police and security calls from the last 24 hours on our website? Our Daily Blotter is updated every weekday morning.


Read the UWPD Blotter »

WiscAlert 101


WiscAlerts is UW-Madison’s emergency notification system – it's a critical tool to keep the campus community informed in an emergency, life-threatening situation.


But, do you know when we activate the system and when we don't? What about alerts for off-campus incidents? And, are you signed up to receive WiscAlert texts on your cell phone?


Learn more about WiscAlerts »

Active threat response: RUN. HIDE. FIGHT.


Chances are you’ll never face an active threat situation. But if you do, you need to be prepared. Visit UWPD's online Active Threat Response Guide – from there you can review the RUN HIDE FIGHT response, watch training videos, and take our online active threat response course.


Learn more »

Newsletter sent by the University of Wisconsin–Madison
‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
View this email in your browser

November 21, 2025

 

WAIT! Don't Send the Pic.


It can start with a friendly message and end with threats or demands for money. Intimacy-based extortion is becoming more common, especially among college students. A few simple precautions can keep you safe when connecting online.


Read more »

Protecting Your Property During Breaks


Heading out of town for break? Before you lock the door and hit the road, it’s worth taking a moment to make sure your space and belongings are set up to stay secure while you’re away. A few quick preventive steps now can help you return to campus with peace of mind and no surprises.

This is a self-directed workout, not an official team session, and can be done on your own time on any day that fits your schedule. Details: ~5 minute warmup (either choice aerobic exercise or a variety of body weight exercises); ~5 minutes light stretching; 3x6 of the following exercises: Forward walking lunges, Med ball throw downs, Rear foot elevated single leg squats; 8 core exercises of choice (45 seconds on/15 seconds rest for each); ~5 minutes stretching. Important: If any questions about proper lifting technique for a specific exercise, do not attempt if unsure on technique to avoid risking injury; ask coach or other team member who is experienced with lifting. Amount of weight used should be challenging on the last few reps but not maxing out; do not risk failure. If unsure of how much weight to use, start on the conservative/lighter side, and increase from there as you feel able.

body_html:
Hi Badgers!

Several of us are conducting original research for our Journalism 202 projects and would greatly appreciate your participation.

Survey 1:

Please fill out this quick survey for a secondhand furniture app class project!

Your perspective is greatly appreciated.

Camryn Fjelstad


Survey 2:

Have you ever wondered about small businesses on campus and how you can support them? Have you ever wanted to start a small business but didn't know how? If you ever have, fill out this very quick survey! 

My name is Grace and I am a student in Journalism 202. For our final project, our lab group is collecting data on the need for an app that focuses on student small businesses and promoting their products. We want to know if students would use the app to buy goods and services from other students or if students with small businesses would use it. 

Please fill out the attached survey, takes 2-3 minutes to fill out and would help use so much!!

Thank you so much!!

Grace Carlson

Survey 3:

Be honest... do you believe in love at UW?

Ok, the real question. Have you ever wished dating apps actually made sense for UW-Madison students? We created a survey about dating app usage on campus and would appreciate it if you took the time to fill it out! The survey is very short and will take less than five minutes to complete.

Thank you!

Aimon Van Houten

subject: Paid Research Study (Sensitive Topic)
preview: This email is about a research study on recovery from unwanted sexual experiences. This is a widespread problem that affects many, and we are aware that this is a sensitive topic. We are sending these emails to randomly-selected undergraduate and graduate
body_html:
This email is about a research study on recovery from unwanted sexual experiences. This is a widespread problem that affects many, and we are aware that this is a sensitive topic. We are sending these emails to randomly-selected undergraduate and graduate students on your campus. We otherwise have no personal information about you or your eligibility for this study. If you are interested in participating or learning more, we have included specific information on our study, next steps for participation, and links to other resources below.
Many students struggle after an unwanted sexual experience. Help us change that.   
Researchers from the University of Washington are trying to find the best possible ways to support survivors after unwanted sexual experiences. If you’ve experienced unwanted sexual contact in the past 3 months, we invite you to help us test an app that aims to help survivors track and support their recovery while promoting their empowerment, autonomy, and privacy.  

You might be eligible for this voluntary, private, and confidential research study if:  
  • You experienced unwanted sexual contact in the past 3 months 
  • You’re struggling with the effects of the experience 
  • You drink alcohol 
  • You’re currently a student at the University of Wisconsin-Madison
If you're eligible, you will be invited to:
  • Use the app and fill out a short check-in survey daily for 21 days
  • Talk to a team member who can help you use the app and provide referrals 
  • Help us understand the impact of the app by completing six 30-minute online surveys over the course of 12 months 
EARN $340+ IN GIFT CARDS 
(if you’re eligible and complete all surveys)  

Help us learn more about this new option for survivors. Learn more and find out if you qualify to enroll today.   
Click to learn more
This study is voluntary and does not affect your eligibility for any other services. If you would like more information about other options for getting support or services for yourself or someone else in your life, please click here.   
The above email may contain patient identifiable or confidential information. Because email is not secure, please be aware of associated risks of email transmission. If you are communicating with a UW Medicine Provider or Researcher via email, your acceptance of the risk and agreement to the conditions for email communications is implied. (See http://www.uwmedicine.org/about/compliance/email-risk).The information is intended for the individual named above. If you are not the intended recipient, any disclosure, copying, distribution or use of the contents of this information is prohibited. Please notify the sender by reply email, and then destroy all copies of the message and any attachments. See our Notice of Privacy Practices at http://www.uwmedicine.org/about/privacy.

todos.content: Use the app and fill out a short check-in survey daily for 21 days
Talk to a team member who can help you use the app and provide referrals
Complete six 30-minute online surveys over the course of 12 months

subject: MadHacks 2025 Walk-In Information — We Want to See You There!
preview:
Hi,

Thank you again for your interest in MadHacks 2025. We wanted to reach out with some important information about walk-in spots.

We received far more strong applications than we had reserved spots available! Because of this overwhelming interest,
body_html:
Hi,

Thank you again for your interest in MadHacks 2025. We wanted to reach out with some important information about walk-in spots.

We received far more strong applications than we had reserved spots available! Because of this overwhelming interest, we're opening up 100 walk-in spots on the day of the event for applicants like you who we couldn't initially reserve a spot for.

Frequently Asked Questions

I didn't get a reserved spot, how do I compete?

If you'd like to compete as a walk-in, here's what you need to do:

  • Show up to Morgridge Hall (1205 University Avenue) on Saturday, November 22nd
  • The walk-in line begins forming at 9:00 AM
  • Walk-in admissions start at approximately 10:30 AM on a first-come, first-served basis
  • Enter through the Orchard Street entrance (the University and Brogden Psychology entrances will be locked due to a Badger football game)
  • View our event schedule on: https://madhacks.io

My teammate got a reserved spot, but I didn't. Can we still compete together?

Absolutely! Your teammate with a reserved spot should check in between 9:00-10:30 AM, and you can join them after successfully getting a walk-in spot at 10:30 AM. Many teams form or add members on the day of the event, so this is completely normal.

What if none of my team got reserved spots?

No problem: your entire team can line up together for walk-in admission starting at 10:30 AM. As long as you arrive early enough in the walk-in line, you'll be able to compete together.

Important Reminders

  • Walk-in spots are first-come, first-served, so we strongly recommend arriving early
  • There will be a Badger football game that day, so parking will be limited. Consider using public transit or carpooling
  • Join our Discord server for real-time updates on the day of the event

We truly appreciate your interest in MadHacks, and we hope to see you on November 22nd. There's a great chance you'll be able to participate, and we're excited to see what you create!

If you have any questions, please don't hesitate to reach out to team@madhacks.io.

Best regards,
The MadHacks Team

--
THE MADHACKS TEAM | Wisconsin's Largest Hackathon
team@madhacks.io
madhacks.io

Join the MadHacks Discord server for real-time updates on the day of the event

subject: Talk Announcement
preview:
Hello everyone:

We will be having a talk by Nan Chen this Friday at 5pm in Van Vleck B123.

Title: Introduction to Uncertainty Quantification

Abstract: I will provide a tutorial on uncertainty quantification (UQ) for those with no background but i
body_html:
Hello everyone:

We will be having a talk by Nan Chen this Friday at 5pm in Van Vleck B123.

Title: Introduction to Uncertainty Quantification

Abstract: I will provide a tutorial on uncertainty quantification (UQ) for those with no background but interested in learning more about this area. The talk will use many elementary examples understandable to undergraduates to present the ideas of UQ. Topics include characterizing uncertainties using information theory, UQ in linear and nonlinear dynamical systems, UQ via data, and the role of uncertainty in diagnostics. These examples explain why and how UQ is essential. Both MATLAB and Python codes have been made available for these simple examples.

There will be pizza provided. Please react with 🍕 on discord if you are planning on attending. We hope to see you there!

todos.content: React with 🍕 on discord to RSVP for the talk.

These examples explain why and how UQ is essential. Both MATLAB and Python codes have been made available for these simple examples. Pizza will be provided.

subject: Invitation: Showcase Your Build Fest Project on Dec. 3 🎉
preview:
Hi everyone,
We’d love to invite you to a bonus opportunity to keep your Build Fest momentum going.
On Wednesday, December 3 (5:30–8:00 p.m.) at the Wisconsin Institute for Discovery, we’re hosting the Lab's Student Demo Night — and you’re invited to pa
body_html:
Hi everyone,
We’d love to invite you to a bonus opportunity to keep your Build Fest momentum going.
On Wednesday, December 3 (5:30–8:00 p.m.) at the Wisconsin Institute for Discovery, we’re hosting the Lab's Student Demo Night — and you’re invited to participate. This event showcases teams who have been working in the Lab this semester, and you are welcome to join in. Here is more about the event.
Why join?
  • Show off your project in a relaxed, high-energy setting
  • Get feedback from alumni, industry partners, and campus leaders
  • Build connections that may open doors
  • Be eligible for Audience Choice Awards of $250 each
What you’ll do
You’ll get a table, can bring a poster or slides, and include a simple “try it” element (demo, click-through, storyboard, etc.). We’ll send details once you sign up.
Interested?
Please fill out this short form by this Friday, 11/21. at 5:00 p.m.
We’d love to see your work represented — it’s a great chance to keep the momentum going.
Best,
Sandra

Sandra Bradley
Executive Director, UW Tech Exploration Lab

sandra.bradley@wisc.edu | Mobile: +1 608-239-3122

events.title: Student Demo Night: Showcase Your Build Fest Project
events.content: A bonus opportunity to keep your Build Fest momentum going. This event showcases teams who have been working in the Lab this semester. You can show off your project in a relaxed, high-energy setting, get feedback from alumni, industry partners, and campus leaders, build connections, and be eligible for Audience Choice Awards of $250 each. Participants will get a table, can bring a poster or slides, and include a simple “try it” element (demo, click-through, storyboard, etc.). Details will be sent after sign-up.

subject: WEM Annual Photo Contest: Submit Today! | Wisconsin Engineer Magazine
preview:

Wisconsin Engineer Magazine
presents
Our Annual Photo Contest!


Want to see your photos published in a campus magazine?

The Wisconsin E
body_html:
The following message is from Wisconsin Engineer Magazine, a registered student organization at UW-Madison. 

Wisconsin Engineer Magazine
presents
Our Annual Photo Contest!
 

Want to see your photos published in a campus magazine?
 
The Wisconsin Engineer Magazine's Annual Photo Contest is here! Submit your photos before Thursday, November 27th for a chance to see your work featured in the Fall 2025 issue of the Wisconsin Engineer.
 
Any UW-Madison student may submit up to three of their own photos in the following categories:
  • Cityscape
  • Landscape
  • Wildlife
  • “In Motion”
  • Still Life
  • Portrait
  • Reader’s Choice
  • Cover Photo
 
Submit by 11:59pm on Thursday, November 27th using this link: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSd7yrbXLFEStP5R3wXsXk4SJ3UGHqgVeo6VOcsZEO59TcrEqQ/viewform
 
Detailed contest rules are linked in the submission form. 

--
You are receiving this one-time email from a Registered Student Organization (RSO) as an enrolled student at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. As one of the benefits provided to RSOs at UW-Madison, groups are allowed to send one mass email per semester.  The Office for Student Organizations, Leadership & Involvement (formerly the Center for Leadership & Involvement) helps to facilitate this process.  RSOs are responsible for providing the content for those messages, with SOLI serving to ensure that content does not violate University policies.  If you have questions or concerns about the mass email process, please contact soli@union.wisc.edu or visit https://guide.soli.wisc.edu/benefits/#on-campus-marketing-resources.  If you have questions or concerns about the content of the message, please find the RSOs contact information via the Wisconsin Involvement Network (WIN) site: https://win.wisc.edu/. Responses to these emails are not monitored.

todos.content: Submit photos for the Wisconsin Engineer Magazine's Annual Photo Contest

subject: EDPOL320 Student Survey Completion Request
preview:
Hi Badgers!

Several of us are conducting original research for our Ed Pol 320 projects and would greatly appreciate your participation.

Survey 1:

I am conducting original research on potential relationships between university students, neighborho
body_html:
Hi Badgers!

Several of us are conducting original research for our Ed Pol 320 projects and would greatly appreciate your participation.

Survey 1:

I am conducting original research on potential relationships between university students, neighborhoods, and proximity to green spaces on campus. To gather data, I am using a survey to collect responses from a broad range of students. It’s a super easy survey, so if you have 5 minutes to take it, that would be greatly appreciated! Thank you!

EDPOL 320 Survey: https://forms.gle/1o63LzjAGXWbVjZg7

Thank you!

Quinn Keyes

Survey 2:

I am gathering data for a final project investigating shifting baseline syndrome. From this survey, I will be able to investigate solutions to this challenge. If you have 2-5 minutes I would really appreciate if you could take the time to fill this quick survey out! The survey is anonymous.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfqIA6r0I8JEs0AvVNZC8R7JkHwedIuXcbhxHEzjyMf6Tudog/viewform?usp=dialog

Thank you!
Maria Gironella

Survey 3:

I am conducting a survey focusing on college-aged students' fashion consumption, which is measured through the amount of clothes you have!

This survey should take less than 15 minutes to complete. Half the survey will require you to be physically in your closet to count pieces of clothing and choose your favorite clothing. It serves as an opportunity to reflect on your clothing consumption and the origins of your clothes. Your survey completion will greatly benefit my data collection. Please share it with your friends and others you know! 

Here is the link again: https://uwmadison.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_2h5LY5Z2V0cNNlQ?Q_CHL=qr

Thank you so much,

Alexa Iraheta




--

Post: https://forms.gle/WGTWCoca8twMk1My5

subject: Join the FIRST EVER Humanoid Robotics Club in UW-Madison!!!
preview:
Join the FIRST EVER Humanoid Robotics club in UW-Madison!

In this club, we will be building a full humanoid robot with dexterous hands, custom actuators, and general-purpose intelligence through VLA (Vision Language Action) models. Our first interest m
body_html:
Join the FIRST EVER Humanoid Robotics club in UW-Madison!

In this club, we will be building a full humanoid robot with dexterous hands, custom actuators, and general-purpose intelligence through VLA (Vision Language Action) models. Our first interest meeting will be on December 2, 6:00-7:00 PM, Room 1610 Engineering Hall, and soon after that we’ll start to design our first prototype.

This is the team people will wish they joined a year from now, and we’re just starting, so you get to participate from the start: in this grand undertaking of building a Humanoid Robot from scratch! Do not miss out this opportunity. Tell your friends and everyone you know!


For more information:

Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/u6P5wu8ywc 
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/wiscohumanoids
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/wiscohumanoids/

Watch Teaser: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aw7vV4zyR4M 
Check Out Our Website: https://www.wiscohumanoids.com/

todos.content: Tell your friends and everyone you know about the Humanoid Robotics Club.

events.title: First Humanoid Robotics Club Interest Meeting
events.content: The first interest meeting for the Humanoid Robotics club, where we will discuss building a full humanoid robot with dexterous hands, custom actuators, and general-purpose intelligence through VLA models.

HEYZ + GUNPOINT

HEYZ'd AND CONFUSED TOUR 360

Support: Powerup | Stikman | K9 b2b Shawnty
Ruby: R!BB!T b2b Debbie Check | Thicc Ellis | Machima | Chris Gnarly

 

HEYZ is bringing his chaotic brainchild straight to the center of the dancefloor 360 style. From viral internet personality to full-fledged touring act, HEYZ has built a cult following through his emotional, heavy bass tunes, and tongue-in-cheek personality. If you’re into bass that absolutely crushes live & have a good sense of humor this is your night.

Catch HEYZ at Liquid for a multi-stage bass takeover that’s going to shake the whole building. (check out his videos on social media, he's hilarious)

PROMO CODE: PITORIS saves 11% till midnight!
Doors at 9PM

 

🎟️ GET TICKETS 🎟️

 

Saturday November 22nd

 

LIQUID 360

 

Liquid 360 features the full 360° setup with the DJ booth in the center, crowd wrapped all around, and lights firing from every angle for a true “in the round” rave experience.

Holding it down all night are Liquid favorites Physicill & Tantra, Kyguy, DJ Mercury, B Roy, Double A, King Woo, and Trance, pushing bass, house, and high-energy club heaters until close.

21+ FREE w/ RSVP | 18+ $10
Doors at 9PM

🔥🎟️CLAIM FREE 21+ EARLY ENTRY🔥🎟️

 

🎟️ GET TICKETS 🎟️

OUTER GROOVE [Ruby]

MVBS & FORGEIN

 

Outer Groove is back in Ruby this Saturday and we’re diving straight into the deep end of house and techno. If you’ve been to an Outer Groove night before, you already know the vibe: heads-down dancers, rolling low-end, shimmering tops, and that warm, locked-in groove that keeps you moving for hours.


Opposite Liquid 360, one ticket gets you into both nights!

21+ FREE w/ RSVP | 18+ $10
Doors at 9PM

 

🎟️ GET TICKETS 🎟️

 

Thursday November 20th

 

Almost Thursday: Boiler Sessions

360 Student Night

 

Tonight, Almost Thursday turns Liquid into a full-send 360 Boiler Room setup for Boiler Sessions. DJs in the middle, crowd wrapped around them, and the energy hitting from every angle. UW-Madison’s top frat and student DJs bringing campus heat straight to the big room with full production.

18+ $10 student tickets
21+ FREE with RSVP
Doors at 9PM

 

🎟️ GET TICKETS 🎟️

 

⚡ UPCOMING EVENTS ⚡

Henry Fong
Ookay
Borgore

subject: Spring Co-Op Orientation- TOMORROW (11/21)-- 3-4 pm, EH 1610
preview:
Good afternoon COE Undergrads,

If you have accepted a co-op offer for the Spring semester, please see important details regarding the upcoming Engineering Career Services Spring Co-op Orientation happening tomorrow--

  *
Friday, November 21st from
body_html:
Good afternoon COE Undergrads,

If you have accepted a co-op offer for the Spring semester, please see important details regarding the upcoming Engineering Career Services Spring Co-op Orientation happening tomorrow--
  • Friday, November 21st from 3:00-4:00 pm in Engineering Hall #1610

Attending an orientation is the first step in getting authorized for the required co-op course.  Attendance is welcomed regardless of whether you have reported your Spring co-op on Handshake or not.  During the orientation session, ECS will cover all aspects of the co-op process from reporting & authorization to course expectations.  Please make sure you attend!  You do not need to register for the session.  The orientation is scheduled as a 60 minute period.


You can find more Co-Op information by utilizing the link to the ECS webpage below:

https://ecs.wisc.edu/students/co-op-and-internship/academic-credit/



Drew Graf

Career Services Advisor

Engineering Career Services

University of Wisconsin-Madison

aagraf@wisc.edu

ecs.wisc.edu

608-262-3356

Schedule an Appointment: https://go.wisc.edu/ecs.appt.graf

todos.content: Attend the Engineering Career Services Spring Co-op Orientation
Find more Co-Op information on the ECS webpage

subject: Participate in a Robot study!
preview:
View Online Version
Researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison seek participants for a human-robot interaction study.

Participants must be 18 years old or older, who do not have extensive experience with robots and who are able to stand for up
body_html:
View Online Version
Researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison seek participants for a human-robot interaction study.

Participants must be 18 years old or older, who do not have extensive experience with robots and who are able to stand for up to 30 minutes, hold and place objects of up to 10 pounds, and interact with a robot. The study will involve interactions with 2 robots and the completion of 2 surveys for a total study time of 30 - 45 minutes in person.

Payment: Participants will make $12/hour for completion of the study.

Study location: Discovery Building 4th floor

If you are interested in participating, please fill out this interest form.

We thank you for your interest in our study!
 
 
The University of Wisconsin-Madison allows researchers to use email to send its faculty, staff, and students information about research opportunities as part of its research mission. The content of this email message has been approved by an Institutional Review Board (IRB). IRBs are charged with protecting the rights and welfare of people who take part in research studies.
Privacy Policy  |   Unsubscribe

todos.content: Fill out interest form for human-robot interaction study

Wisconsin Union
 

Join the 2026 Homecoming Committee

Hey Evan!

Looking for a new leadership role on campus? Join the UW Homecoming Committee and help plan incredible events that create excitement on campus and among alumni. To apply for the 2026 Committee, fill out the application form before November 30 at 11:59 PM.
Apply Now

Why Lead? 

  • Plan one of UW–Madison's longest-standing traditions.
  • Advance your leadership and event planning skills with other leaders and organizations.
  • Network with current students and Badger alumni.
  • Create and maintain experiences that make a difference on campus.
  • Get involved and have fun!
 
A Wisconsin Union Experience
 
 
 
 
Unsubscribe from emails like this or manage your subscription preferences.

View Workout
Workout

WiTri- Strength Workout 4

Time

1

hr

Pre-workout comment

There is not an official team strength workout as a group, but this can be done on your own or w/training partner(s) on your own time. Does not have to be on Friday, can be on whatever day fits your schedule the best. If any questions about proper lifting technique for specific a specific exercise, do not attempt if unsure on technique to avoid risking injury. Ask coach or other team member who is experienced with lifting. Amount of weight used should be challenging on the last few reps but not maxing out- do not risk failure. If unsure of how much weight to use, start on the conservative/lighter side, and increase from there as you feel able.

Description

~5 minute warmup- either choice aerobic exercise or a variety of body weight exercises

~5 minutes light stretching

3x6 of the following exercises:
-Forward walking lunges
-Med ball throw downs
-Rear foot elevated single leg squats

8 core exercises of choice- 45 seconds on/15 seconds rest for each

~5min stretching

subject: Engineering construction update: Nov. 20, 2025
preview:
Dear faculty, staff and students:

I’m writing to share information about engineering campus construction activities that may affect you in the coming week. You can find all construction updates, along with a map, on the project update page at facilitie
body_html:
Dear faculty, staff and students:
 
I’m writing to share information about engineering campus construction activities that may affect you in the coming week. You can find all construction updates, along with a map, on the project update page at facilities.engr.wisc.edu. Please understand that this update is our best attempt at providing information about major impacts and activities that affect the main engineering campus; however, many factors out of our control may affect day-to-day operations and we ask for your patience with all involved.
 
Important
  • Pedestrians: Please avoid walking down Engineering Drive or Randall Avenue. Use designated sidewalks and crosswalks and refrain from walking in roadways or crossing mid-street. A map of approved pedestrian routes is available on the project update page at facilities.engr.wisc.edu.
  • Vehicles: Be mindful of pedestrians in crosswalks; if you need to pause while traveling through campus, please keep crosswalks open. Please obey posted speed limit signs.
  • Please obey flagger signals. Whether you are on foot, in a vehicle or using other transportation, these people are there to keep you safe when construction equipment is operating outside fenced areas.
  • Plan ahead and keep your eyes up. Take extra care when traveling through or near the engineering campus. Be aware of construction and related vehicles entering and exiting various locations. Please avoid all fenced areas and construction trailers near the UW Athletics facilities. And most importantly, be patient and tolerant — your cooperation helps keep everyone safe.
 
New info: Changes and closures anticipated in the week ahead
  • Beginning tomorrow (Nov. 21) through Nov. 23, the Engineering Research Building will be transitioning chilled water from the old to new systems. Building occupants have received separate emails with details.
  • Over the next week or more, pedestrian walkways along Engineering Drive will shift due to work happening in front of Engineering Hall. Additionally, one of the adjacent crosswalks may close temporarily. Watch for signs and fencing to help you navigate this area.
 
Ongoing
  • The WIAA state football tournament is ongoing through tomorrow. Many out-of-town visitors may be traveling through our campus; please be extra vigilant.
  • Pile driving will continue for the Phillip A. Levy Engineering Center. (There is a map forecasting pile driving locations on the project updates page on our facilities website.)
  • At times, you may notice odors in buildings adjacent to construction activity. Most of these odors are temporary; however, if the odors persist, please contact our facilities team at coe-facilities@engr.wisc.edu. If needed, arrange an alternate work location with your supervisor.
  • Running through December, there is a temporary pedestrian path through Engineering Mall from Engineering Hall to University Avenue.
  • The Engineering Research Building loading dock is closed (however, see future planning, below). Mail and shipping staff will operate out of the Engineering Centers Building receiving area; you can find contact information for these individuals on the loading dock door.
  • Semi deliveries can no longer be accepted at College of Engineering loading docks. We would like most deliveries requiring an elevated dock to go to MDS; however, larger items on flatbeds that cannot be accepted by MDS should be coordinated by contacting our facilities team at coe-facilities@engr.wisc.edu.
 
For future planning or awareness
  • We anticipate that during the week of Dec. 1, one Engineering Research Building loading dock bay will open.
  • We anticipate that during the week of Dec. 1, pile driving in front of the Engineering Hall plaza will continue.
  • We anticipate that crews will be removing piles on Dec. 1 and 2 from the area in front the Engineering Research Building.
  • In the future, crews may be lifting scaffolding onto the Mechanical Engineering Building roof in the traffic lane between the Engineering Centers Building and ME, as well as the area adjacent to the Engineering Research Building loading dock.
 
Please be careful and aware: Whether you are on foot, bike, scooter, moped, in a vehicle, or otherwise, be alert and know what's happening around you. If you see an immediate safety concern, please reach out to Pete Nemmetz, college assistant dean for facilities, right away, at pnemmetz@wisc.edu.
 
As always, many factors, including weather and other unknowns, may impact construction activities. If our contractors need to make unanticipated changes, I ask that you respect their instructions, and be patient with them and others.
 
Once again, our goal is to keep you informed about what's happening for your safety and route-planning purposes.

Thank you,
David

**********************************
David A. Noyce
Executive Associate Dean
Arthur F. Hawnn Professor of Transportation Engineering

Plan ahead and keep your eyes up when traveling through or near the engineering campus
Be aware of construction and related vehicles entering and exiting various locations
Avoid all fenced areas and construction trailers near the UW Athletics facilities
Watch for signs and fencing to help navigate shifting pedestrian walkways along Engineering Drive
If odors persist, contact the facilities team at coe-facilities@engr.wisc.edu
If needed (due to odors), arrange an alternate work location with your supervisor
Coordinate larger items on flatbeds that cannot be accepted by MDS by contacting the facilities team at coe-facilities@engr.wisc.edu
If you see an immediate safety concern, reach out to Pete Nemmetz at pnemmetz@wisc.edu

THE BUZZ

Happy Thursday, Evan! This week, we’re celebrating Land that we Love events, recapping the first leg of the Energy Freedom Tour, and highlighting the latest edition of The Bully Pulpit.

WHAT BUSY BEES

Photo credit: @acc.campbell and @acc.unc


From November 7th through the 16th, ACC branches showed up in a big way serving communities, honoring veterans, and caring for the places we call home. And wow…you made an impact!


The Land that We Love events at ACC branches across the country reinforced that the heart of conservation is always local and grassroots.


ACC branches hosted everything from veteran appreciation events and Thanksgiving food drives to park cleanups and conservation projects, giving back to their communities and the people who make this country special.



If you or your branch hosts an event, don’t forget to email your photos to ryan@acc.eco so we can highlight them in the next edition of The Buzz!

View the Highlights Here!


ENERGY FREEDOM AT A&M WAS LIT

ACC and The Hamm Institute just wrapped the 2025 leg of the Energy Freedom Tour at Texas A&M!


We were honored to be joined by Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins, CEO of the Bush Foundation Alice Gonzalez Yates, Devon Energy CEO Clay Gaspar, Entra1 Energy’s Skip Alvarado, and Howard Energy CEO Mike Howard.


The tour's mission? Champion American energy abundance and connect students with high-impact careers that fuel our nation’s future through The Legacy Center.


Next Up This Spring: UNC Chapel Hill, CU Boulder, and Ohio State.

Learn more about the Energy Freedom Tour

FROM THE HIVE

ACC’s newest blog post: The Sun is Setting on Nuclear Stagnation


Meet ACC Dallas’s Reed Olsen: Voyage Dallas

FROM THE BULLY PULPIT

In the latest regular edition of ACC’s new Substack, The Bully Pulpit, ACC COO Stephen Perkins argues for optimistic, solution-oriented action to combat climate doomerism.


If you haven’t already, make sure you subscribe today to catch more deep dives into policies, collaborative partnerships, and updates on the conservative conservation movement.

Subscribe to The Bully Pulpit Today

ATTENTION, HIVE MEMBERS

  • ACC is hiring! We are looking for a Mobilization Manager, Utah State Director, and Development Associate. Check out our Careers page here.

  • Interested in civic leadership? Join The Policy Circle for the CLER 1.0 Program! Applications are due January 25, 2026. For more information, click here.

We Want to Share Your News

MEME OF THE WEEK

subject: Final Drop/Withdrawal Deadline is Mon, Nov. 24th
preview:
Dear Undergraduate Engineering Students,

The final deadline to drop course(s) or withdraw from the university is Monday, November 24th. If you are considering dropping a course or withdrawing, we encourage you to consult with your instructors and acade
body_html:
Dear Undergraduate Engineering Students,

The final deadline to drop course(s) or withdraw from the university is Monday, November 24th. If you are considering dropping a course or withdrawing, we encourage you to consult with your instructors and academic advisor as soon as possible.

If you plan to drop a course or withdraw from all your classes, the drop/withdrawal must be completed by 11:59 p.m. on Monday, November 24th. You should also confirm in your Student Center that you were successful in dropping the course(s).

Note: These deadlines only apply to full semester-length courses. To see the deadlines for other courses, check Course Search & Enroll.

INTERNATIONAL STUDENTS (F-1/J-1):  Please work with ISS before you attempt to drop or withdraw from the semester. Learn more Reduced Credit Loads or Leave of Absence.

DROP COURSE(S)

If you are unsure about whether to drop any course(s), I encourage you to take the following steps:

  • Speak with your instructor for the course(s) in question. Professors and TAs can help you understand where you stand in the course and what it will take to achieve a desired grade.
  • Communicate with your academic advisor. Your advisor is listed in your MyUW Student Center. Your advisor can help you understand the impact of dropping a class (e.g. meeting progression requirements, satisfying prerequisites for future courses, time to degree, remaining full-time).

Step-by-step instructions for dropping courses are at: https://kb.wisc.edu/registrar/15256
Please note that dropping a course is different from withdrawing from the semester. Withdrawal is described below.

WITHDRAW from UW-Madison

Withdrawing means the system will drop all of your courses and you will not remain an enrolled student. If you are considering withdrawing from all of your courses, you need to:

  • Contact your engineering academic advisor. Your advisor is listed in your MyUW Student Center. If you are considering a withdrawal, first speak to your advisor as soon as possible. Answers to questions about the withdrawal process and implications of withdrawing are at: https://kb.wisc.edu/registrar/25151.
  • Fill out and submit the online withdrawal form. The form is in your MyUW Student Center – Manage Classes – Enrollment Term Withdrawal: https://registrar.wisc.edu/how-to-withdraw/.
  • Medical withdrawal. Medical withdrawals may be granted to students who experience a serious or unexpected physical or behavioral health condition that precludes them from being able to function as a student; who may need to provide care to an immediate family member who is experiencing a serious or unexpected physical or behavioral health condition; or who have experienced the death of an immediate family member. Approval will be granted on a case-by-case basis. Learn more about medical withdrawal: https://registrar.wisc.edu/medical-withdrawal/.

Again, a withdrawal is only to be used if you want the university to drop all your courses and not remain a student for the rest of the semester.

NEED SUPPORT?

If you are concerned for the well-being of yourself or someone you know, please call UHS Mental Health helpline at 608-265-5600 (option 9) to speak with an on-call crisis counselor. This service is always available, including weekends, holidays, semester breaks, and all summer.

Uwill: UHS Mental Health Services (MHS) is partnering with Uwill to expand access to flexible, no-cost, virtual counseling options for UW-Madison students starting with 3 sessions with a Uwill counselor. Licensed mental health professionals are available for video, phone, chat, and message sessions during flexible hours – including nights and weekends. Students can get in quickly to see a counselor, with appointments typically available within 24 hours. https://www.uhs.wisc.edu/mental-health/uwill/

SPEAK with Assistant Dean Rachel Jones

Is there anything you need help with as you navigate the end of the semester? In my position, I often work with students to help them identify the challenges they are facing, understand all of their options moving forward, and then help them create strategies and plans to be successful. Your advisor and I want to work with you! Please feel free to respond to this email.

 

Rachel Jones
Assistant Dean for Student Services

College of Engineering
2640 Engineering Hall

Office: (608) 890-3692

rejones5@wisc.edu


Student Appointments Schedule HERE

 

“Education must not simply teach work—it must teach life.” W.E.B. Du Bois

 

Concerned about a student? Click here to fill out a student of concern report

 

UW-Madison 24-hour crisis services: 608.265.5600 (select option 9 for crisis services)

988 Suicide & Crisis Lifeline (call or text 988)

E-mail is not checked outside of business hours or on weekends. If you are experiencing a crisis, please contact our 24-hour crisis services, dial 911, or go to your nearest emergency room.

From: Evan Weilun Liu <eliu59@wisc.edu>
Sent: Wednesday, November 19, 2025 7:51 PM
To: CS Advising <advising@cs.wisc.edu>; Grant Gao <ggao36@wisc.edu>
Subject: Re: Humanoid Robotics Club Outreach––First General Meeting
 
Hi, I'm just wondering if you have seen the email? Or is there a place where I can submit a form to be included in the newsletter? Thanks

Get Outlook for iOS
From: Evan Weilun Liu
Sent: Saturday, November 15, 2025 9:39:20 PM
To: CS Advising <advising@cs.wisc.edu>; Grant Gao <ggao36@wisc.edu>
Subject: Humanoid Robotics Club Outreach––First General Meeting
 
Hi CS Advising,
This is Evan! I’m reaching out regarding the first meeting of this newly founded humanoid robotics club. Could you help me include this outreach message in the next weekly newsletter?

Thank you so much!

–––———————————————————————
Join the FIRST EVER Humanoid Robotics club in UW-Madison!

We will be building a full humanoid robot with dexterous hands, custom actuators, and general-purpose intelligence through VLA (Vision Language Action) models. Our first interest meeting will be on December 2, 6:00-7:00 PM, Room 1610 Engineering Hall, and soon after that we’ll start to design our first prototype.

This is the team people will wish they joined a year from now, and we’re just starting, so you get to participate from the start, in this grand undertaking of building a Humanoid Robot from scratch! Do not miss out this opportunity. Tell your friends and everyone you know!


Join our Discord: https://discord.gg/u6P5wu8ywc 
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/wiscohumanoids
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/wiscohumanoids/

Watch Teaser: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aw7vV4zyR4M 
Check Out Our Website: https://www.wiscohumanoids.com/

todos.content: Include Humanoid Robotics Club outreach message in the newsletter.

­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­ ­

With the conclusion of this off-year election cycle, I want to express my deepest appreciation for all the work you put in both through the CRNC’s Voter Contact Initiative and in your local community elections. The results of this year were broadly disappointing, but they tell us we have no time to waste! As soon as you get back from winter break, the midterm cycle begins!


Ian Waite

Executive Director

 

GIVING TUESDAY TEAM

This year, the CRNC is piloting a brand-new project to give members a chance to participate in our Giving Tuesday campaign. The students who participate, the Giving Tuesday Team, will fundraise among existing CRNC supporters, prospective donors, and their own communities, expanding our reach and making a real impact.


Participants will receive training, resources, and support during the 2-week campaign and can expect to spend about 10-15 hours total on the effort.


If you’ve ever wanted to play a bigger role in strengthening chapters, growing our movement, and building the resources we need for 2026… this is your chance!

Join the Team

VOTER CONTACT INITIATIVE RECAP

This cycle Voter Contact Initiative focused on the off-year elections in Virginia and New Jersey. CRs across the country delivered real impact through direct, targeted voter engagement. In total we hosted 1 weekend of action, sponsored 27 campus call nights, and had over 300 individual members participate throughout the cycle!


Next cycle begins at the start of the spring semester!

NEW MERCH

Take a peek at the new merch available in the CRNC store, just in time for Christmas! Please keep shipping & handling can take up to 12 days from the date of order.

Shop

COMING UP…

Tuesday, December 2 - Giving Tuesday

December 15 - January 31 - CRNC Winter Term Internship

January 1, 2026 - Rechartering Begins

CRs IN THE NEWS

Shout out to the Washington & Lee University College Republicans for their recent panel.


The W&L CRs hosted the three members of Congress who are also W&L alum for a conversation on the future of American Foreign Policy. This was the first time in school history that all W&L alumni serving in Congress gathered on campus at the same time. This event drew the largest crowd of any political event on campus in the past three years.


Great work Generals!

events.title: Bucky! Documentary Premiere
events.content: PBS Wisconsin’s new historical documentary narrated by comedian Charlie Berens — premieres. Travel through the stacks and carrels of UW libraries in search of archived Bucky Badger images and materials with Head of Archives Katie Nash to help bring our favorite furry mascot’s history to life.

subject: Fundamentally Sound A Cappella Fall Show!
preview:
Hello Badgers!


Fundamentally Sound is having its annual Fall Show, and we would love to see you there!


Have you ever thought to yourself, “Dang, those guys on State Street singing and riding a moped are REALLY cool, I wonder if they sing more th
body_html:
Hello Badgers! 


Fundamentally Sound is having its annual Fall Show, and we would love to see you there!


Have you ever thought to yourself, “Dang, those guys on State Street singing and riding a moped are REALLY cool, I wonder if they sing more than Birthday Sex?” Well, good news, we do! This year, our Fall Show will have a huge range of musical artists and genres. Not only will we be singing the very iconic ‘Birthday Sex,’ but other bangers such as ’Skate' by Silk Sonic, ’Toes’ by Zac Brown Band, ‘Fools’ by Troye Sivan, and so much more! 


If you are looking to fulfill your Pitch Perfect dreams, then this concert is for you! Our show is THIS FRIDAY, November 21st, 7 PM at the Masonic Center. Don’t miss your chance not only to win the opportunity to get ‘Birthday Sex’ sang to you, but also to experience some of the best A Cappella entertainment you can find on campus. We hope to see you there!


Interested? Check out our ticket link: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/fundamentally-sound-fall-show-feat-the-michigan-g-men-tickets-1809816703479?aff=ebdsoporgprofile



Thank you, and happy Holidays!


Fundamentally Sound 


--

Post: https://forms.gle/F6FjJBEVgjDtaH5fA
Housing—Sublets
View: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1F0WQTDbb0ThFl1A3BhEl5HdX82gJZK96L0OaKj27mgg
Post: https://forms.gle/WGTWCoca8twMk1My5
--
Invite your friends to join this group by having them email all-student-bulletin-board+subscribe@g-groups.wisc.edu.
If you prefer to no longer receive information on campus events from your fellow classmates, you can unsubscribe by emailing all-student-bulletin-board+unsubscribe@g-groups.wisc.edu.
--
Made possible with the support of your student government representative, Amitabha Shatdal. Please email shatdal3@wisc.edu if you would like to become a moderator or work on developing this bulletin board.

It’s the season for big sales and deep discounts. So if you’re scoping out good deals for a shiny new device, follow these steps to enroll it in Duo. Don’t forget: Generate a list of backup passcodes, too!

Change to student access tokens in Canvas

If you wish to use an access token, you’ll now need to request one.
 

UW grads: Make sure your name is correct for winter commencement

Graduating this December? Let’s make sure your name records are ready for the commencement ceremony and your diploma.

Help Desk hours over Thanksgiving recess

The DoIT Help Desk will have reduced hours, and we’ll be closed on Thanksgiving Day. Please make note of these changes. Enjoy your break, Badgers!

Looking for an IT mentor?

Interested in a career in information technology? Make connections and grow your skills in 2026! Apply by Dec 10 to be paired with a mentor.
 

Microsoft Copilot Chat now available in M365 applications

Copilot, Microsoft’s AI tool, is now available in Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook and OneNote. Learn about the new features that come with Copilot’s expansion.
 
TechNews is your campus newsletter about software and computing services, technology trends, user tips, service enhancements and workshops. Published by the UW–Madison Division of Information Technology (DoIT). Thanks for reading.

Submit your ideas & feedback • Why do I receive this email? • Outages
 
Computer Sciences, 1210 West Dayton Street, Madison, WI 53706

If you wish to use an access token in Canvas, request one.

subject: Free ECG Screening Drive | Cardiac on Campus
preview:
The following message is from Cardiac on Campus, a registered student organization at UW-Madison.
Hello Badgers!
Cardiac on Campus is excited to host their 8th Electrocardiogram (ECG) Screening Drive on Sunday, December 7th, from 11:30 - 3:30 pm in the
body_html:
The following message is from Cardiac on Campus, a registered student organization at UW-Madison. 
Hello Badgers!
Cardiac on Campus is excited to host their 8th Electrocardiogram (ECG) Screening Drive on Sunday, December 7th, from 11:30 - 3:30 pm in the Student Activities Center! The event is FREE to everyone (ages 10 to 25), so come along with your friends and family, even if they aren’t UW-Madison students! A screening will only take 5-10 minutes at a time that fits your convenience! Registration is available at https://www.whoweplayfor.org/wisconsin-dane.
Why should you get a screening?
The following is a quote from a previous participant: “I signed up for Cardiac on Campus’s ECG Screening just to support the organization – I was assuming my results would come back perfectly normal. However, the cardiologist who reviewed my ECG noted that I had Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which prompted me to have more testing done and be seen by an electrophysiologist. Before Cardiac on Campus’s event, I had no idea that I had a heart condition. Even if you don’t think you need an ECG, just do it! You never know what results you might have.”
According to the American Heart Association, “cardiac arrest is the abrupt loss of heart function in a person who may or may not have been diagnosed with heart disease. It can come suddenly or in the wake of other symptoms and is often fatal if appropriate steps aren’t taken immediately.” A common misconception is that cardiac arrest only occurs in the older population. However, cardiac arrest can happen to anybody regardless of age. Young, active individuals lose their lives to cardiac arrest every year. In fact, Cardiac on Campus was founded in 2015 after a healthy 20-year-old Oshkosh student, Jon Derynda, went into sudden cardiac arrest and passed away after a charity run with his family. His sister, Brittany Derynda, and cousin, Jessica Miller, were both UW-Madison students who wanted to create this organization in his memory and spread more awareness about the importance of heart health.
An ECG will measure the electrical activity of your heart. With this recording, medical professionals that we are partnered with can interpret the electrical activity of your heart and determine if it is abnormal, which may mean you are at risk of experiencing sudden-onset cardiac arrest. ECG screenings can be done with a doctor at a hospital, but this would cost roughly $200, with some variance depending on insurance plans. Cardiac on Campus’s ECG Screening increases access to this test at no cost to you!
Any questions can be directed to Jack Sperling at jwsperling@wisc.edu. 
Hope to see you there!
The Cardiac on Campus Executive Board

--
You are receiving this one-time email from a Registered Student Organization (RSO) as an enrolled student at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. As one of the benefits provided to RSOs at UW-Madison, groups are allowed to send one mass email per semester.  The Office for Student Organizations, Leadership & Involvement (formerly the Center for Leadership & Involvement) helps to facilitate this process.  RSOs are responsible for providing the content for those messages, with SOLI serving to ensure that content does not violate University policies.  If you have questions or concerns about the mass email process, please contact soli@union.wisc.edu or visit https://guide.soli.wisc.edu/benefits/#on-campus-marketing-resources.  If you have questions or concerns about the content of the message, please find the RSOs contact information via the Wisconsin Involvement Network (WIN) site: https://win.wisc.edu/. Responses to these emails are not monitored.

todos.content: Register for the Electrocardiogram (ECG) Screening Drive
Direct any questions about the event to Jack Sperling at jwsperling@wisc.edu

subject: Seeking participants for a **VIRTUAL** UW-Madison Research Study
preview:
View Online Version
UW-Madison Neurology is seeking participants for a study on the long-term cognitive development of children, including healthy infants and those who had a history of a perinatal brain injury.

You may be able to join the study if yo
body_html:
View Online Version
UW-Madison Neurology is seeking participants for a study on the long-term cognitive development of children, including healthy infants and those who had a history of a perinatal brain injury.

You may be able to join the study if you:
  • Have a healthy child up to 6 months of age with no prior history of a brain and or cardiac illness early in life, OR
  • Have a child up to 6 months of age who was diagnosed with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, cerebral palsy, and/or was born premature at less than 28 weeks gestational age.
As part of this research study, your child will complete an online game and assessments. Parents will be asked to fill out questionnaires.

Study participation will entail 4 virtual appointments over the course of 2 years. Compensation up to $175 will be provided for your participation.

Time Commitment: 45-60 min per visit.

If you are interested in participating or have any questions about the study, please email: sprint@neurology.wisc.edu
 
 
The University of Wisconsin-Madison allows researchers to use email to send its faculty, staff, and students information about research opportunities as part of its research mission. The content of this email message has been approved by an Institutional Review Board (IRB). IRBs are charged with protecting the rights and welfare of people who take part in research studies.
Privacy Policy  |   Unsubscribe

todos.content: Email sprint@neurology.wisc.edu to express interest in participating or ask questions about the UW-Madison Research Study.

events.title: UW-Madison Virtual Research Study Participation
events.content: Participation in a study on the long-term cognitive development of children. Involves 4 virtual appointments (45-60 minutes each) over the course of 2 years. Children will complete online games and assessments, and parents will be asked to fill out questionnaires. Compensation up to $175 will be provided.

WiTri- Strength Workout 3

Time

1

hr

Pre-workout comment

There is not an official team strength workout as a group, but this can be done on your own or w/training partner(s) on your own time. Does not have to be on Wednesday, can be on whatever day fits your schedule the best. If any questions about proper lifting technique for specific a specific exercise, do not attempt if unsure on technique to avoid risking injury. Ask coach or other team member who is experienced with lifting. Amount of weight used should be challenging on the last few reps but not maxing out- do not risk failure. If unsure of how much weight to use, start on the conservative/lighter side, and increase from there as you feel able.

~5 minute warmup- either choice aerobic exercise or a variety of body weight exercises

~5 minutes light stretching

3x6 of the following exercises:
-RDL or trap bar deadlift
-Pullups or lat pull downs
-Calf raises
-Single arm dumbbell chest press

8 core exercises of choice- 45 seconds on/15 seconds rest for each

~5min stretching

Ask coach or other team member who is experienced with lifting. Amount of weight used should be challenging on the last few reps but not maxing out- do not risk failure. If unsure of how much weight to use, start on the conservative/lighter side, and increase from there as you feel able. Description: ~5 minute warmup- either choice aerobic exercise or a variety of body weight exercises. ~5 minutes light stretching. 3x6 of the following exercises: -RDL or trap bar deadlift -Pullups or lat pull downs -Calf raises -Single arm dumbbell chest press. 8 core exercises of choice- 45 seconds on/15 seconds rest for each. ~5min stretching.

events.title: WiTri
events.content: 15min warmup. 10x(20s standing, 40s seated). 5min easy. 10min tempo 75-90% FTP, 5min easy. Group 1- 3x(4min hard 100-120% FTP, 6min easy). Group 2- 4x(4min hard 100-120% FTP, 6min easy). Group 3- 4x(5min hard 100-120% FTP, 5min easy).

subject: Journalism 202 Study Abroad Survey
preview:
Hello Badgers!

Are you planning on studying abroad? Have you studied abroad before? Do you plan on staying here in Madison for your entire undergraduate career? Not sure yet? If you fall into any of these categories, you should fill out the attached su
body_html:
Hello Badgers!

Are you planning on studying abroad? Have you studied abroad before? Do you plan on staying here in Madison for your entire undergraduate career? Not sure yet? If you fall into any of these categories, you should fill out the attached survey! 

My name is Micah and I’m a student in Journalism 202. As a part of the final project for the course, our lab sections are conducting surveys to better understand student demographics on certain topics. We’ve created a survey asking questions depending on if you have, plan to or do not want to participate in study abroad. The survey will take about 1-2 minutes to complete, is completely anonymous and helps us understand UW Madison students' opinions on studying abroad. We’re trying to reach as many students as possible to fully understand the student body’s opinions, so your answers will help us immensely!

Here is the link to the survey: https://uwmadison.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_1Y8GK2jmnSATvvg. Thank you in advance for your participation!

Thank you, 
Micah Cannariato

From: Bryce Sprecher <bjsprecher@wisc.edu>
Date: Tuesday, November 11, 2025 at 21:04
To: Evan Weilun Liu <eliu59@wisc.edu>
Subject: Re: UW Tech Lab Ai Coding Tools Sbuscription

Hi Evan,

Thanks for reaching out. Sandra and I are scheduled to review lab purchasing tomorrow, so this is good timing.

To clarify a few points

Cost: There's a misunderstanding about the pricing. The Cursor Ultra subscription is actually twice the cost of the Claude Max plan, not the same price. This would make it the most expensive subscription we've considered, not an even swap.

Current Usage: I can confirm the Claude Max subscription is still active and in use. As a lab policy, we don't reallocate resources from one team to another without a formal discussion with all users involved.

If we are able to move forward with a subscription, we would need to set up the paid account under our lab email. This means your team would need to be able to transfer or port your project to this new account. Please confirm if that process would work for your team.

Best,

Bryce
From: Evan Weilun Liu <eliu59@wisc.edu>
Sent: Monday, November 10, 2025 5:57 PM
To: Bryce Sprecher <bjsprecher@wisc.edu>
Subject: UW Tech Lab Ai Coding Tools Sbuscription
 

Hi Bryce,

This is Evan. I spoke with Sandra today about the AI coding tool subscriptions, and she mentioned you’re the right person to ask.

We were wondering if the Tech Lab could pause the current Claude Max subscription and switch to a Cursor Ultra subscription instead. From what I know, the other project that used Claude Max doesn’t seem to be using it anymore. If you’re using the tool, usually you have to verify the email every month, but I haven’t seen any verification emails from them this past month, so I doubt if they’re still using the tool.

Since these two subscriptions are both $200/month, could you help check if people in that project are still using the Claude Max subscription, and if not, whether it’s possible for the Tech Lab to allocate this same funding to the Cursor Ultra subscription to our project, UW Match?

Thanks!
Evan Liu

subject: Materials Advantage Membership
preview:
Hello,

Every year our chapter is required to submit a roster of current students here at Madison to the national Materials Advantage organization. If you havent resgistered before or havent renewed your membership for next year, visit the Material Adva
body_html:
Hello,

Every year our chapter is required to submit a roster of current students here at Madison to the national Materials Advantage organization. If you havent resgistered before or havent renewed your membership for next year, visit the Material Advantage Membership Portal. 

There is a 25$ membership charge, however MA provides a large variety of scholarships for all students to apply too. Additionally to attend any conference, you are required to be a MA member. 

They also ask everyone ensure that their demograohic info is updated on the MA portal, specially anticipated graduation dates, email addresses, and mailing addresses.

Once you've renewed or registered, please fill out this form: Material Advantage Membership

Feel free to reach out over slack or respond to this email with any questions or concerns!

Thank you,
MAAFS Board

todos.content: Visit the Material Advantage Membership Portal to register or renew membership for next year.
Ensure demographic info is updated on the MA portal (anticipated graduation dates, email addresses, and mailing addresses).
Fill out the Material Advantage Membership form after renewing or registering.

To: Sandra Bradley <sandra.bradley@wisc.edu>
Subject: Re: UW Match--Mentor Support and Connection
 
Hi Sandra, I have provided a short introduction for my project and the things that I need the most help with. Could you help me forward this email to your CS faculty connections or the industry connections? I would greatly appreciate it!

Best Regard,
Evan Liu

From: Evan Weilun Liu <eliu59@wisc.edu>
Date: Monday, November 10, 2025 at 17:41
To: Sandra Bradley <sandra.bradley@wisc.edu>
Subject: UW Match--Mentor Support and Connection

Hi, my name is Evan,
Currently, I’m working on this project UW Match, the website can be found in uwmatch.com. The goal for this project is to design a student-centered course planning app. In this app, students can find all kinds of course information in one place, they can also plan courses and validate their major requirements. We have developed a lot of useful features for this app. Students can easily upload their degree plan PDF to load their courses, when they plan their courses, the major requirements progress is updated in real time for all majors the user has chosen. We scraped course information from several places, and provide features like checking grades distribution, RateMyProfessors, course sections and instructors, and more. The final goal for this project is to be the go-to place for students to plan courses, as it provides an all-in-one solution that actually solves the students’ needs.

I’m not the most experienced in terms of organizing a large codebase with ongoing new features and refining. Therefore, I often encountered a lot of problems as I’m developing this project to make it better for everyone. If possible, I would like to have a mentor that I could consult with to help with organizing the codebase, frontend design, API design, data models, data analytics as well as how to create algorithms for a scheduler tool, course recommendations and more.

Thank you!
Evan Liu

todos.content: Check for the advisor confirmation form regarding Bucky Match sent by SOLI
Forward Evan's project introduction email to CS faculty or industry connections for mentor support
